Hav Kerloe 5/28/2022 5:03 PM
I wake up. Another morning. I look out my window and see the city of Avengard from my apartment. I have the same thought I have every morning—thousands of people are also waking up now. Very interesting. It's Monday. As the owner of Kerloe Fishery, I work all seven days of the week, but business only truly is active on the weekdays. Exponentially more people will be present than they were yesterday and the day before, which is good. Mondays are interesting. They're clearly different from the two days before them, and according to society, those two days are better. There's not really a difference, we've just assigned things to work this way. I'm reminded of the famous comic strip cat Carlfield, who is known for hating Mondays. Why does the cat hate Mondays? The reason people hate Mondays is because they have to work, and they didn't have to work on the two previous days. However, cats don't need to work, do they? Cats are animals. That's the thing about Carlfield, and all the cats like him. They don't need to do anything. Carlfield hates Mondays because humans hate Mondays. Humans hate Mondays because there is a collective agreement that Mondays should work this way. So, what's the point in Carlfield putting in energy to rebel against the idea of hating Mondays? It's much simpler for him to accept that Mondays are bad, and to hate them. Carlfield is not funny. I'm not sure why John David's comic strip cat is so popular when there are so many other comic strips just like it out there. I'd guess it was because he was one of the first to do it. I myself understand John David's methods, as I was one of the first to open a fish store in the city of Avengard. There are other fish stores now, because people see success and wish to emulate it, but since I was the first, I am the most successful. I look towards the tank of fish in my room. I open a tube of fish food, and give it to the fish. I'm keeping the fish alive. Why? For the same reason that I go to work and sell fish, or for the same reason Carlfield eats his lasagna. Very simply, I'm not sure. We just do it. I'd love to speak to John David about his decision to make Carlfield eat lasagna. Lasagna is fascinating, because it combines pasta, sauce, and meat. Meat is the result of us looking at an animal that cannot communicate anything to us, and saying that its life must be used to make food. Food tastes good. Something tasting good is good, because we like it. Carlfield, however, is equally as much a commodity as the cows that result in his lasagna. He's bought by James Carlbuckle and kept as a pet. Just like the fish I just fed. However, fish are arguably the ideal animal, because they can be treated with pure equality. At the fish store, I sell fish as food to be eaten. At home, I keep fish as pets. I can visit the ocean, and see fish in the wild, living their lives to the fullest, with no human intervention. Fish are truly incredible. With the thoughts of Carlfield in my mind, I exit the bedroom. I chuckle thinking about the infamous "pipe strip", in which Carlfield steals James's pipe. I am not amused because Carlfield is funny, but because of how absurd this joke is. It's barely even a joke. It's amusing how bad of a joke it is. (edited)

Hav Kerloe 5/28/2022 5:38 PM
There are three rooms in my apartment, and I enter the second one. It is a kitchen, but I prefer to call it the fish room, because there are several fish tanks in it. Ironically, the fish room is also where I cook and eat fish. As much as I would love to cook a delicious fish breakfast, my work takes priority. I enter the third and final room of the apartment, the restroom. I brush my teeth—an important activity, though I'm unsure why. I wonder if Carlfield brushes his teeth. He takes the idea of hating Mondays from humans, despite it being meaningless to him, so why not brushing teeth as well? Finally, I feed the many fish in the fish room. I wonder which is more important—feeding the fish, or brushing my teeth? What a fascinating dilemma. However, the answer is obvious—of course feeding the fish is more important. Brushing my teeth does not keep me alive. Feeding the fish does keep them alive. If I stopped feeding the fish, it would affect their lives, it would kill them. As the owner of a fish store, I am responsible for the deaths of many fish. Of course, the lives of fish are unimportant. I don't know why this is, but it's true. I'm suddenly struck with an idea. I reach my hand into one of the tanks, and take a fish out of it. I rush to my bedroom with the squirming fish in my hand, and open the window. I then drop the still living fish out of it, onto the streets of Avengard below. I close the window, and return to the fish room. I'm spreading fish to the people. What a wonderful thought, someone being able to witness the death of a fish right before their eyes. Will they understand? Will they see that this doesn't matter, because society has told them that this fish's life is meaningless? Will they be confused as to why a fish is dying right in front of them? They shouldn't be. Why would a fish's death only matter if you specifically are the one who witnesses it? Like Carlfield eating his lasagna, people are ignorant to the idea that things must happen to cause their everyday activities. Yes. I will write to John David and tell him my idea. I grab a pen and a piece of paper, and begin to write. To John David, creator of Carlfield I think that it would be very interesting if you were to have a Carlfield comic strip in which Carlfield must confront the ways his beloved lasagna is made. He would be disgusted at first, but he would realize that there is no reason to be discomforted by this, and understand that he always knew that his lasagna would be made like this. Seeing it makes no difference. This realization could also potentially spur Carlfield into understanding why his hatred of Mondays is illogical—he is a cat, not a human. Human logic does not matter to him. I do not require credit for use of my idea. Thank you, Hav Kerloe (owner of Kerloe Fishery) I place the letter in an envelope, then attach the requisite postage stamps to the envelope. I wonder how I will find out where to send this letter for it to reach John David. I don't use the internet, so looking it up there would not be possible. I decide that I will ask the next person I communicate with to search it for me. I take the letter and a pen and place them in my pocket. I then take my keys and exit my apartment. (edited)

Hav Kerloe 5/28/2022 9:54 PM
It's very ironic that Sam claims he doesn't find a lot of daily events interesting, because that might be the most unique thing I've seen today. Daily events are only the way that they are because they happen "daily", no? The idea that things happen the same way every day "just because" is so interesting. Sam here is questioning that, and his questioning is the closest thing I've seen today of someone who is willing to rebel against those same "daily events". That same question is also why he won't accomplish anything by thinking this. If you don't pay attention to the existence of the world's repetition and sameness, then despite being someone who can break the pattern, you won't be conscious enough to be able to make a meaningful difference. When you consider how Sam claimed "it's not a huge deal", it's clear he won't succeed. Sam also claimed that he wondered if I did either, implying that he thinks I am being dishonest with him. Of course, I would never lie to someone. Why? Because I don't want to. Carlfield saying that he hates Mondays is lying. He doesn't hate Mondays, he just hates the idea of them. Any person claiming that they hate Mondays would be a liar, because the thing they hate is the way society structures the days of the week, not the day itself. The reason the world exists in the state that it does is because everyone is a liar. The idea that I would be dishonest is laughable. Lying is thinking there is a chance to exit the state you are in—there isn't. We are here because we want to be, and we should be satisfied with that. So, how should I respond? Should I even respond at all? It's possible that I could help Sam by giving a certain kind of response, but do I really need to? Does helping him really accomplish anything? I guess it would keep him coming back here, which would be good. The more time one spends around fish, the better a person they become, after all. If I help Sam, everyone wins. And he clearly needs help to "understand". Thus, I decide to respond in the kindest way possible, in hopes that it will encourage his continued patronage. "I hope you have a great day." (edited)

Hav Kerloe 6/18/2022 3:36 PM
I wake up. Another morning. I look out my window and see the city from my apartment. I have the same thought I have every morning—thousands of people are also waking up now. The city is called Avengard, and I'm not entirely sure why. I think about Shelk, the other city to the south of Avengard. Why are these two cities separate? This is the type of thing that the citizens of Avengard and Shelk are forced to ponder every day, I'm sure. It's Tuesday. Another day that I, as the owner of Kerloe Fishery, must work. This is good, because I get to make money, which helps me survive. Tuesdays aren't quite as interesting as Mondays, as they are unrelated to Carlfield the cat, who is known for hating Mondays specifically. Tuesdays are a normal day, like all the others. What do Tuesdays do to stand out? Nothing. Tuesdays are, honestly, a failure of a day. I look towards the fish tank that I keep in my room. I then look towards the fish food tube placed next to it. I place my hand onto the tube's lid, and unscrew it. This process opens the tube, allowing the fish food within to exit the tube freely. It's interesting to note how, in the ocean, fish food doesn't exist. Fish simply must eat whatever is available to them. It's incredible how they are able to know what it is to eat, and they are blessed with the ability to access that at any time. When humans eat fish, we have to prepare them, make sure they are made in the right way. It's a process that is dedicated to taking the fish's existence and distilling it down to a "meal". The irony in that is that the fish themselves must be fed first with food of their own. Humans can't eat fish food. Why not? What's the problem with it? If the food goes into the fish, and the fish goes into us, then... This doesn't make sense at all. I stare at the open tube of fish food. I then pick it up and pour the contents of it into my mouth, and swallow.

Hav Kerloe 6/18/2022 4:50 PM
Surprisingly, the fish food tastes awful. Is this what the fish go through? Is this what humans force them to eat? This torture is what they must go through, sitting in tanks, consuming the most vile food imaginable, until their death? A death that dooms them to be food themselves. What a beautiful existence. Fish know what they are. They know they must eat to survive. They know that continuing to survive is a thing they must do. At the same time, they live in complete ignorance. They have nothing to compare themselves to, no way of knowing how much better it could be. I realize that, since I have swallowed all of the fish food, I don't have any fish food left to feed the fish with. This is bad. I must feed the fish. If I do not feed the fish, they will die. I cannot simply let the fish die. I'm not hungry, and it would be a waste. I've already introduced a live fish to the people yesterday, so they must understand. Doing it again would be pointless. I'm not sure what to do. ... It hits me. I will buy more fish food. I've figured out the solution to this dilemma. I exit the bedroom, satisfied that such an elegant solution to all of my problems has shown itself to me.

Hav Kerloe 6/18/2022 5:20 PM
I enter the second of the three rooms in my apartment, that I affectionately call the "fish room". The reason for this is because, contained within the room, are several fish tanks, each with several fish inside them. Contrary to popular belief, the head is the best part of eating fish. Consuming the eyes and mouth of the animal, its view into the world, cements the idea that this object of consumption was once a living thing. We see out of our eyes, just like this fish did. I pour some olive oil on the pieces, then add salt for flavoring. I then add some cayenne pepper from a container that carries the spice—a classic accompaniment for this type of fish. Finally, I peel a clove of garlic and mince it, then add the pieces to the dish. After the oven is finished preheating, I place the cod in it and wait for ten minutes. Hav Kerloe 8/27/2022 2:32 PM
What a fascinating strip, as expected of Carlfield. First, the joke. We can look at this one on several levels, but the most noteworthy aspect of the joke is in how Carlfield's opinion of himself contrasts with James's analysis of his actions. This type of distinction can create a very comedic scenario, as James represents the average reader's view of society, and Carlfield represents what the average reader truly wants—a life free from responsibilities. It's "relatable" in that way. Indeed, the underlying message here could not be clearer—John David is telling us that Carlfield believes in this lifestyle, and through that, he's saying that this lifestyle is wrong. Carlfield is demonized for having this belief, and the fact that he isn't a responsible worker like James makes it clear that he lacks a certain quality that drives humans to do work—motivation. Carlfield, however, is not a human, and therein lies another one of the major themes of the Carlfield saga—the divide between human and animal, and how it's not necessarily as clear-cut as one might imagine. Carlfield is here, struggling against human perceptions of responsibility, and what he should do. But Carlfield's thought process is the same, his sentience is the same, and his way of living is the same. Being an exploration of the human experience through the lens of a nonhuman figure is the core thesis of Carlfield, and this strip exemplifies it greatly.
2:32 PM

Ehn/PC 8/27/2022 2:44 PM
"Fan Mail 1:
To John David, creator of Carlfield I think that it would be very interesting if you were to have a Carlfield comic strip in which Carlfield must confront the ways his beloved lasagna is made. He would be disgusted at first, but he would realize that there is no reason to be discomforted by this, and understand that he always knew that his lasagna would be made like this. Seeing it makes no difference. This realization could also potentially spur Carlfield into understanding why his hatred of Mondays is illogical—he is a cat, not a human. Human logic does not matter to him. I do not require credit for use of my idea. Thank you, Hav Kerloe (owner of Kerloe Fishery)
Thank you very much for your input, Hav! I’m always glad to hear the requests of devoted fans, and the Carlfield team loved your clear devotion for the work they put in every day. These comic strips are more than just a hobby, or even a job. You could consider them almost like my entire life. They’re my legacy. And every day, I wake up happy to know people more creative than me love and appreciate that lovable orange cat. You’re right, maybe human logic doesn’t matter to Carlfield. But despite this fact, he still chooses to apply it to his life anyway. Maybe life is not as simple as human logic, or cat logic. Perhaps just as Carlfield enjoys lasagna, we may enjoy cat food in the world of comic strips. Thank you so much for your devotion to Carlfield."

WHAT THE FUCK??????????????????????? THIS CHANGES EVERYTHING????????????????????????????? It smells like fish! Fish!!!!! Not only that, but it looks like fish! Do cats eat fish????? I had a plan for what I was going to do, but I'm completely caught off-guard now. This is incredible. You're telling me that Carlfield, the representation of all that is true in the world, decides to eschew his cat food, which is made of fish, for his lasagna? This is... Utterly brilliant! I can't believe I spent any time doubting John David's genius! He knows exactly what he is doing. He knows far more than I do, that's certain. I take a moment to reflect on what I am wearing. White suit, bandages to cover the face. An appearance masked by a distinct yet plain outer layer. Why do people consider this, a covering of all that individualizes you, a unique or strange way to be? Why is the default state one of difference between all people? WHY DOES THE CAN OF CAT FOOD HIDE THE EXTREME IMPORTANCE WITHIN? The fact is that there is fish inside the can. Just as there is a skeleton in every human. These fish are processed, cut up, and packed tightly into cans to be shipped off and enter the inside of a cat. The core of their being, their destiny, is hidden—never to be truly understood by human observers. Perhaps this is why humanity is so ignorant. If reality was entirely clear, it would cease to be the same reality. If distinctions between individuals cannot be made, recognition of the illogical nature of distinctions would be unnecessary. Is that what Carlfield represents? His world is one where Mondays are dreaded, despite this not making any sense from his perspective. His world is one where he loves lasagna, despite his own designated food being fish of all things. Carlfield is a comprehensive attack on the benefits of uniqueness—his most notable traits are ones that do not function under any scrutiny, he is in complete denial of everything around him, and he is miserable. Over and over, Carlfield is punished for attempting to leave the position he belongs in. The statement John David is making is revolutionary. I can only imagine the calamity that would befall human society if his true intentions were known by the masses. I was going to eat the fish food, but I can't do that now. This is far too important a symbol to be carelessly consumed like that. I decide instead that I should burn it, in hopes that some trace amount of the smoke will reach the inside of John David's nostrils, out of respect for how much he's accomplished. Hav Kerloe 10/8/2022 3:10 PM
Ah... Now this a brilliant work. There's so much depth here. If I were to summarize this strip, I would describe it as a symbol of how the unrelenting pressure of individuality conflicts with the world's natural order. Carlfield, as is obvious, represents life as it truly is. He represents a struggle to understand the self, a struggle to accept your place in reality. His owner, James, is, in short, confused. He's an ordinary human in the presence of such an indescribable power, and he subconsciously copes with what this results in. The individual, non-concurrent shenanigans that occur show just how volatile their lives are. With the knowledge of the true contents of cat food, an entirely new dimension of analysis is unlocked. This strip revolves around food. In the first panel, health. Things that James believes will make him stronger. Broccoli, spinach, brussels sprouts, tofu, and raisins. All of these are things that Carlfield cannot bear the existence of. There's no reason to be against "healthy" foods. Taste is irrelevant to a being with as much power as Carlfield. The utter incoherence of his desire to maintain the human norms of "good taste = good food" and "bad taste = bad food" is baffling, and this is clearly a conscious choice on John David's part. The "SMACK" in the second panel—what an unbelievable moment. This is a clear representation of the shift in roles, the way Carlfield's smack acts as a punishment for James, the way James's tongue extends to an over-exaggerated length, just like an animal's would. In this moment, James has become the pet, and Carlfield has become the owner. The fragility of the hierarchy between these two beings is put on full display here. After this shift, despite James taking the same actions he does in the first panel, it becomes clear that there is now an entirely different system governing their world. Three pats, and a thought that James is a "good boy"—Carlfield, with a single smack, has taken full control of the situation, being able to destroy what society held up in an instant. The metaphorical can of cat food has been opened, revealing the fish inside. James, now under the control of Carlfield, returns to writing his list, this time writing foods that Carlfield believes he likes. The key word there is "believes"—Carlfield is a cat, and thus is entirely unburdened by what human perception deems as good or bad. Yet, he still undergoes the same rituals. He places himself in the role of a human and acts out a facsimile of one. In doing this, John David has illustrated something truly revolutionary—an expression of the weakness of human roles, and a demonstration of their shallowness. (edited)
Ehn/PC 10/8/2022 3:37 PM
This comic has clearly flown far over Hav's understanding of these comics. Of course, these comics dissect human consciousness and their social structures. That’s what they were designed to do. All of them serve as a scathing critique of everything that drives humanity. Pointing this out on its own isn’t complex analysis, it’s the expected bottom line of quality. Should a story be praised for even completing its most basic expected functions? Of course not. There is so much more to it.
